reg.acttitle: Community Care and Assisted Living Act
reg.title: Child Care Licensing Regulation
reg.amsincluded: [includes amendments up to B.C. Reg. 457/2004, October 22, 2004]

subsection.subsectiontext: In this regulation:

definition.def: means the Community Care and Assisted Living Act;
means a person who has the qualifications required by section 11;
means a certificate issued under section 8 of the Act or section 9 of the Community Care Facility Act before its repeal;

definition.term: director of the early childhood educator registry
definition.def: means the person responsible for

paragraph.paragraphtext: issuing certificates to educators under sections 9, 10 and 13, and
varying, suspending, or cancelling certificates under section 14,

section.defsandwich: that being the person described in section 8;

definition.def: means an early childhood educator certified under section 9, and a special needs early childhood educator and an infant and toddler educator certified under section 10;
means the provision, in a group setting, of care to children and of opportunities for their social, emotional, physical and intellectual growth;

definition.term: local assistant to the fire commissioner
definition.def: means "local assistant" as defined in the Fire Services Act;
, in respect of a person in care, means

paragraph.paragraphtext: the guardian of the person in care,
the person legally entitled to custody of the person in care, or
the person who usually has the care and control of the person in care;

definition.def: means a reportable incident described in Schedule F;

means a community care facility in which care and opportunities for social, emotional, physical and intellectual growth are provided to persons in care who are placed in the community care facility to receive 24 hours of care and supervision each day, but does not include a community care facility referred to in section 36;
means a person who has the qualifications required by section 12;
means children who, because of physical, mental or emotional handicaps, require additional support and services;
means a person designated, in writing, by the parent of a person in care as a substitute parent of the person in care.

subsection.subsectiontext: For the purpose of paragraph (a) of the definition of "care" in section 1 of the Act, the prescribed programs are those regulated by the following Parts of this regulation:

section.parasandwich: Part 4 [Group Day Care, 30 Months to School Age];
Part 11 [Child Minding, 18 Months to School Age];
Part 11.1 [Occasional Child Care at Ski Hill or Resort].

subsection.subsectiontext: For the purposes of paragraph (b) of the definition of "care" in section 1 of the Act, the prescribed program is that regulated by Part 9 [Residential Care] of this regulation.

section.marginalnote: Exemptions under section 16 of the Act

subsection.subsectiontext: An applicant for an exemption under section 16 of the Act must provide, in writing and in a form acceptable to the medical health officer, the information requested by the medical health officer.

If the exemption requested under subsection (1) is not granted, or is not granted in full, the medical health officer must provide to the applicant for the exemption written reasons for not granting the exemption or for not granting part of the exemption.
The medical health officer may grant an exemption to any section of the Act or regulation, except those listed in Schedule G.
In determining whether to grant an application under subsection (1) for a variation to

paragraph.paragraphtext: an exemption that was granted to a licensee or applicant for a licence under section 5 (3) of the Community Care Facility Act, R.S.B.C. 1996, c. 60, before that section was repealed,
a substitute requirement that was imposed on a licensee or applicant for a licence under section 5 (4) of the Community Care Facility Act before that section was repealed,

an alternative arrangement approved by the medical health officer under sections 15 (3), 30 (1.1), 30.1, 33.1, 36.1 (1), 67.1 (1), or section 10 of Schedule E of this regulation before those provisions were repealed, or
an authorization granted under section 51 (2) (a) before that provision was amended,

section.subsandwich: the medical health officer must accept the exemption, substitute requirement, alternative arrangement or authorization on its face and consider only the merits of the application under subsection (1).

subsection.subsectiontext: In addition to any information required by the medical health officer under subsection (1), a licensee who is applying to temporarily place or retain in a facility a child who does not meet the requirements specified in the definition of "child" in sections 37, 42, 47, 52, 57, 61, 71, 76 or 80.1, as applicable, must show that

paragraph.paragraphtext: the temporary placement or retention is in the best interests of the child, and
none of the following limits or ratios specified for the facility, as applicable, are exceeded:

subparagraph.subparagraphtext: the maximum size of a group, however determined;
the maximum number of children cared for or living in a facility at one time, however determined;
the ratio of employees to children.

subsection.subsectiontext: An applicant for a licence to operate a community care facility must

paragraph.paragraphtext: submit an application to the medical health officer, and
provide, in the form specified by the medical health officer, the information set out in subsection (3).

subsection.subsectiontext: An applicant for a licence must immediately notify the medical health officer of any change in the information provided under subsection (1) (b).
An application referred to in subsection (1) must be accompanied by

paragraph.paragraphtext: a statement of the qualifications, relevant work experience and suitability of the person who is proposed to be the manager of the community care facility,
3 references and a criminal record check under the Criminal Records Review Act for

subparagraph.subparagraphtext: the applicant, if the applicant is not a corporation, and
the proposed manager, if the manager is different than the applicant,

paragraph.paragraphtext: a statement of the number of employees, excluding the manager, the applicant proposes to employ and their qualifications,
a brief description of the program to be offered at the community care facility,
a floor plan of the proposed community care facility drawn to scale and showing

subparagraph.subparagraphtext: the inside dimensions of each room and the width of each corridor and stair,
the size and location of the fixed equipment in each room,
the location and size of windows and the height of windowsills from the floor, and
the location of accommodation reserved for family or staff,

paragraph.paragraphtext: a site plan of the proposed community care facility drawn to scale and showing

subparagraph.subparagraphtext: the boundaries of the property on which the community care facility is located,
the location of the community care facility, and
the location and dimensions of the play area,

paragraph.paragraphtext: a statement of projected monthly revenue and expenditures, including the estimated cost of employee salaries, food, utilities, maintenance, housing and programs,

if the play area is not within the boundaries of the property on which the community care facility is located, a sketch map showing the location of the play area in relation to the community care facility and its distance from the community care facility, and
if the applicant is a society, a copy of the constitution and bylaws of the society.

section.sectiontext: A licensee must notify the medical health officer

paragraph.paragraphtext: immediately of any change in the information provided under section 3, and
before any structural alteration is made to a community care facility.

subsection.subsectiontext: A licensee must not employ a person in a community care facility unless the licensee is satisfied of the person's good character and suitability for employment in the community care facility after the licensee

paragraph.paragraphtext: obtains a criminal record check under the Criminal Records Review Act for the person, and
examines character references for the person.

subsection.subsectiontext: The licensee must not permit a person over the age of 12, other than a person in care or a parent of a person in care enrolled at the community care facility, to be ordinarily present on the premises of a community care facility during the time that persons in care are present, unless the person is of good character and the licensee has obtained a criminal record check under the Criminal Records Review Act for that person.

If the licensee is not a corporation, the licensee must be of good character and must submit to the registrar under the Criminal Records Review Act an authorization to obtain a criminal record check under that Act for the licensee.
The licensee must retain all results of the criminal record check referred to in this section as long as the subject of the criminal record check remains an employee of the community care facility.

The licensee must retain records of all character references done under subsection (1) (b) for at least one year, after which the records must be returned to the person who was the subject of the check or be destroyed.
The licensee must retain all signed original authorization forms for a minimum of 5 years.
The licensee must not employ a person in a community care facility as

paragraph.paragraphtext: an educator, unless the person has the appropriate certificate, or
an assistant or responsible adult, unless the person has the qualifications required by section 11 or 12, as applicable.

subsection.subsectiontext: A licensee must ensure that each of its employees who works in or about a community care facility, at all times,

paragraph.paragraphtext: possesses the personality, ability and temperament necessary to maintain the spirit, dignity and individuality of the persons being cared for,
possesses the training and experience and demonstrates the skills necessary to carry out the duties assigned to the employee, and
is physically and mentally competent to carry out the duties assigned to the employee.

subsection.subsectiontext: A licensee who is not the manager of the community care facility must ensure that the manager

paragraph.paragraphtext: is a person of good character,
has the personality, ability and temperament necessary to manage a community care facility in a manner that will maintain the spirit, dignity and individuality of the persons being cared for, and
is physically and mentally competent to carry out assigned duties.

subsection.subsectiontext: A manager must not manage more than one community care facility.

section.marginalnote: Director of the early childhood educator registry

subsection.subsectiontext: The director of the early childhood educator registry is the person who occupies the position of Executive Director of the Child Care Programs and Services Branch of the Ministry of Children and Family Development.
The director of licensing must perform the duties and functions of the director of the early childhood educator registry if all of the following apply:

paragraph.paragraphtext: there is no person described in subsection (1) or that person is unable to act;
there is no person acting for a person described in subsection (1) or that person is unable to act;
there is no deputy to a person described in subsection (1) or that person is unable to act.

section.marginalnote: Qualifications for an early childhood educator certificate

subsection.subsectiontext: The director of the early childhood educator registry may issue an early childhood educator certificate to an applicant who

paragraph.paragraphtext: has successfully completed a basic early childhood education training program

subparagraph.subparagraphtext: through an educational institution listed in item 1 of Schedule B, or
that is equivalent, in the opinion of the director of the early childhood educator registry, to a program offered by an educational institution described under subparagraph (i),

paragraph.paragraphtext: has completed 500 hours of work experience in Canada

subparagraph.subparagraphtext: within 5 years after completion of a training program described in paragraph (a),
in not more than 2 community care facilities as defined in section 37, 42, 47, 52, 57, 71 or 76, and
under the direction of

clause.clausetext: an educator, if the work experience is completed in the Province, or
an individual acting in a position equivalent to an educator in a child care setting outside the Province, in any other case,

paragraph.paragraphtext: is recommended by the person or persons under whose direction the work experience was completed and who can attest to the applicant's suitability to act as an educator, and
is of good character.

subsection.subsectiontext: If an applicant has, in qualifying for another profession, completed a course that the director of the early childhood educator registry considers is at least equivalent to a course forming part of a training program referred to in subsection (1) (a) (i), the director of the early childhood educator registry may exempt the applicant from the requirement to complete that course.

For the purpose of subsection (1) (a) (ii), the director of the early childhood educator registry may refuse to issue a certificate to a person solely on the basis that the educational institution from which the person received training is not approved by a provincial, state, national or other government body.
The director of the early childhood educator registry may issue a special needs early childhood educator certificate or an infant and toddler educator certificate to an applicant who

paragraph.paragraphtext: qualifies for an early childhood educator certificate under section 9, and
has successfully completed, as applicable,

subparagraph.subparagraphtext: a special needs early childhood educator training program through an educational institution listed in item 2 (a) of Schedule B,
an infant and toddler educator training program through an educational institution listed in item 2 (b) of Schedule B, or
a program that is equivalent, in the opinion of the director of the early childhood educator registry, to a program offered by an educational institution described under subparagraph (b) (i) or (ii).

subsection.subsectiontext: For the purpose of subsection (1) (b) (iii), the director of the early childhood educator registry may refuse to issue a certificate to a person solely on the basis that the educational institution from which the person received training is not approved by a provincial, state, national or other government body.

section.sectiontext: To qualify for employment in a community care facility as an assistant, a person must

paragraph.paragraphtext: be of good character,
be able to provide care and mature guidance to persons in care, and
either

subparagraph.subparagraphtext: be in the process of qualifying for a certificate under section 9, or

have completed a training program that is equivalent, in the opinion of the director of the early childhood educator registry, to one course of a basic early childhood education program referred to in section 9 (1) (a) (i).

section.sectiontext: To qualify for employment in a community care facility as a responsible adult, a person must

paragraph.paragraphtext: be of good character,
have reached 19 years of age,
be able to provide care and mature guidance to persons in care,
either have completed a course on the care of young children or have relevant work experience, and
if persons in care in a residential care facility are

subparagraph.subparagraphtext: less than 6 years of age, have completed a course on the care of young children or have relevant work experience, or
from 6 to less than 19 years of age, have completed a course in the care of children or youths or have relevant work experience.

section.marginalnote: Expiry and renewal of a certificate

subsection.subsectiontext: A certificate expires on the 5th anniversary after its date of issue.
On application before a certificate expires, the director of the early childhood educator registry may renew a certificate if satisfied that

paragraph.paragraphtext: the applicant is of good character, and
during the term of the current certificate, the applicant

subparagraph.subparagraphtext: has completed 300 hours of work experience in the field of early childhood education, and
has

clause.clausetext: attended at least 2 seminars, conferences or workshops on early childhood education, lasting a total of at least 12 hours, or
completed a course relating to early childhood education.

subsection.subsectiontext: On application after a certificate expires, the director of the early childhood educator registry may issue a new certificate if satisfied that

paragraph.paragraphtext: the applicant is of good character,
during the term of the expired certificate, the applicant completed the requirements set out in subsection (2) (b) (i) and (ii), and
the applicant's failure to apply before the expiry of the certificate was due to circumstances beyond the control of the applicant.

section.marginalnote: Variation, suspension or cancellation of a certificate

subsection.subsectiontext: In this section:

definition.def: , in relation to a certificate, means a decision by the director of the early childhood educator registry

paragraph.paragraphtext: to attach or vary terms or conditions of a certificate, or to suspend or cancel a certificate, under subsection (2), or
not to issue a new certificate under section 13;

definition.def: means a written response referred to in subsection (3) (b).

subsection.subsectiontext: The director of the early childhood educator registry may attach or vary terms or conditions of a certificate, or suspend or cancel a certificate, if, in the opinion of the director of the early childhood educator registry, the certificate holder

paragraph.paragraphtext: no longer meets the requirements in section 6 (2) of this regulation, or
has engaged in conduct that detrimentally affected, or may detrimentally affect, the health, safety or well being of a person in care.

subsection.subsectiontext: Thirty days before taking an action, the director of the early childhood educator registry must give the certificate holder

paragraph.paragraphtext: written reasons for the action, and

written notice that the certificate holder may give a written response to the director of the early childhood educator registry setting out the reasons why the director of the early childhood educator registry should make a decision under subsection (4) respecting the action.

subsection.subsectiontext: If the director of the early childhood educator registry considers that this would be appropriate in the circumstances, the director of the early childhood educator registry may, on receipt of a written response,

paragraph.paragraphtext: delay or suspend the implementation of the action if

subparagraph.subparagraphtext: the director of the early childhood educator registry requires further time to consider the written response or for an investigation under section 4 (1) (d) or 15 (1) (b) or (d) of the Act to be completed, and
it is reasonable to conclude that, if the delay or suspension is granted, the health or safety of no person in care will be placed at risk, or

paragraph.paragraphtext: take the action.

subsection.subsectiontext: The director of the early childhood educator registry must give written reasons to the certificate holder on acting or declining to act under subsection (4).

A certificate holder may not give the director of the early childhood educator registry a further written response concerning an action on or after receipt of written reasons under subsection (5) concerning the action.
The licensee must display the following in a prominent place in the community care facility:

paragraph.paragraphtext: the licence, including any terms or conditions of the licence;
the name of the manager;
a copy of the current certificate of each educator employed at the community care facility.

subsection.subsectiontext: Subsection (1) does not apply if the community care facility is located in a private single family dwelling as defined in section 9 (7) of the Act.

section.sectiontext: The licensee must

paragraph.paragraphtext: ensure that, before a person is employed in a community care facility, the person provides the licensee with the written opinion of a medical practitioner that the mental and physical health of the person is adequate for the duties to be assigned,
require each employee, as a condition of employment, to comply with the Province's immunization and tuberculosis control programs, and
keep records respecting each employee's compliance with and participation in the programs referred to in paragraph (b) and, on request, make the records available to the medical health officer.

subsection.subsectiontext: The licensee must ensure that the applicable ratio of employees to persons in care, as set out in this regulation, is maintained in a community care facility at all times.
If an educator is absent from a community care facility, the licensee must appoint another educator or an assistant to assume the responsibilities of the absentee.
If an assistant is absent from a community care facility, the licensee must appoint an educator, another assistant or a responsible adult to assume the responsibilities of the absentee.
If a responsible adult is absent from a community care facility, the licensee must appoint an educator, an assistant or another responsible adult to assume the responsibilities of the absentee.
If an employee absence exceeds one month, a person who is less qualified than the absentee must not be appointed under subsection (2), (3) or (4) without the approval of the medical health officer.
The licensee must immediately notify the medical health officer if the manager resigns or is expected to be absent from duty for more than 21 consecutive days.
The licensee must immediately notify the medical health officer of any changes in the permanent personnel.

The licensee must ensure that persons in care, while at the community care facility or on an outing organized by employees, are under the supervision of an employee who is capable of ensuring that effective communication will take place during an emergency.

section.sectiontext: The licensee must ensure that persons in care are supervised at all times by a responsible adult, an educator or an assistant, and that a second adult is readily available.

section.marginalnote: Release of a person in care from a community care facility

subsection.subsectiontext: The licensee must obtain in writing from a parent of a person in care, and maintain at the community care facility, the name of each person authorized to remove the person in care from the community care facility.
The licensee must ensure that a person in care is not released from a community care facility to anyone except

paragraph.paragraphtext: a parent of the person in care, or
a person authorized under subsection (1).

subsection.subsectiontext: The licensee must have written policies and procedures to guide employee actions when

paragraph.paragraphtext: a person referred to in subsection (2)

subparagraph.subparagraphtext: appears to be incapable of providing safe care, or
does not arrive to pick up the person in care, or

paragraph.paragraphtext: a person not authorized under subsection (1) requests the release of the person in care from the community care facility.

section.sectiontext: The licensee must ensure that a parent of a person in care has reasonable access to a person in care while that person in care is in the community care facility.

subsection.subsectiontext: The licensee must maintain at the community care facility current records showing the following information in respect of each person in care:

paragraph.paragraphtext: name, sex, date of birth, medical insurance plan number and immunization record;
date of enrolment in the community care facility;
daily attendance record;
name and telephone number of a parent, medical practitioner and emergency contact person;
any therapeutic diet or special instruction that is recommended or given by a medical practitioner and of which a parent or the medical practitioner has notified the licensee in writing;
any medication that is prescribed by a medical practitioner or provided by a parent that the licensee has agreed to administer, and any instruction on administering that medication;
the times any diet referred to in paragraph (e) is given or medication referred to in paragraph (f) is administered;
any other instruction given by a parent;
any illness or medical disability disclosed to the licensee by the person in care or their parent or medical practitioner.

subsection.subsectiontext: The licensee must obtain in writing from a parent of a person in care, and maintain at the community care facility, consent for employees to call a medical practitioner or ambulance for the person in care in case of accident or illness, if the parent of the person in care cannot immediately be reached.

If a licensee has agreed with a parent to give a person in care any medication prescribed by a medical practitioner or provided by the parent, the licensee must ensure that the medication is administered to the person in care in the amount and at the times specified in the person in care's record.
A licensee must ensure that medication is not given to a person in care while under the care or supervision of the licensee, except in accordance with subsection (1).

A licensee must immediately notify a parent of a person in care or the person named for that purpose in the person in care's record under section 21 (1) (d) if, while under the care or supervision of the licensee,

paragraph.paragraphtext: the person in care becomes ill or is injured, or
the person in care is involved in a reportable incident.

subsection.subsectiontext: A licensee must notify the medical health officer within 24 hours after

paragraph.paragraphtext: a person in care is involved in a reportable incident while under the care or supervision of the licensee, or

it comes to the attention of the licensee that a person in care enrolled in the community care facility has a reportable communicable disease as defined in section 1 of the Health Act Communicable Disease Regulation, B.C. Reg. 4/83.

subsection.subsectiontext: A licensee must maintain a log of

paragraph.paragraphtext: minor accidents and illnesses that do not require medical attention and are not reportable incidents, and
unexpected events involving a person in care.

section.marginalnote: Person in care who becomes ill
section.sectiontext: The licensee must

paragraph.paragraphtext: provide in the community care facility a quiet, clean resting area for persons in care who become ill while under the care or supervision of the licensee, and
ensure that a person in care who becomes ill is under the close supervision of an adult.

section.sectiontext: The licensee must establish a program for persons in care enrolled in a community care facility to instruct them in, and to practise the rules of, health and hygiene.
The licensee must

paragraph.paragraphtext: provide and maintain first aid kits approved by the medical health officer,
ensure that first aid kits are readily accessible to the employees of a community care facility at all times, both on and off the premises, and
ensure that persons in care have immediate access to an employee who holds a valid first aid certificate awarded to the employee after completion of a course listed in Schedule C.

section.sectiontext: The licensee and the employees of a community care facility must ensure that

paragraph.paragraphtext: all medications are kept in a locked container, and
no poisonous substance or potentially hazardous object is accessible to a person in care.

section.sectiontext: The licensee must

paragraph.paragraphtext: establish emergency procedures before the opening of the community care facility and ensure that all employees are thoroughly trained in the procedures, and
post and practise a system of fire drills approved by the local assistant to the fire commissioner.

section.sectiontext: The licensee must ensure that there is an operating telephone within the community care facility and that the telephone is readily accessible to all employees.

subsection.subsectiontext: The licensee must supply appropriate equipment, furniture and supplies and must ensure that any equipment, furniture or fixture in the community care facility

paragraph.paragraphtext: is of sturdy, safe construction, is easy to clean and is free from hazards, and
is placed so that it will not interfere with exits.

subsection.subsectiontext: The licensee must ensure that the community care facility is cleaned on a regular basis and that a reasonable level of cleanliness is maintained at all times.
The licensee must

paragraph.paragraphtext: provide employees and parents with a written statement of the community care facility's policy on discipline, and
ensure that no person in care is, while under the care or supervision of the licensee, subjected to any of the following, including as a form of punishment:

subparagraph.subparagraphtext: shoving, hitting, shaking, spanking or any other form of corporal punishment;
harsh, belittling or degrading treatment, whether verbal, emotional or physical, that would humiliate the person in care or undermine the person in care's self respect;
confinement, physical restraint or separation, without adult supervision, from other persons in care;
deprivation of meals, snacks, rest or necessary use of a toilet.

subsection.subsectiontext: The licensee must ensure that a person in care is not, while under the care or supervision of the licensee, subjected to emotional abuse, physical abuse, sexual abuse or neglect as those terms are defined in Schedule F.

section.sectiontext: The licensee must provide to persons in care a comprehensive and coordinated program of activities that

paragraph.paragraphtext: is designed for the development, care and protection of persons in care,
is appropriate for the age and development of the persons in care in each group in the community care facility, and
meets the standards set out in Schedule D.

subsection.subsectiontext: The licensee must ensure that, weather permitting, persons in care enrolled in a community care facility, other than in a residential care facility or a community care facility defined in section 76, have regular daily play periods in an outdoor play area that complies with the requirements of this regulation.
The licensee of a residential care facility must ensure that, weather permitting, persons in care have an opportunity for outdoor activities each day.
The licensee must ensure that an outdoor play area in a community care facility is enclosed by a fence.

section.sectiontext: The licensee must ensure that

paragraph.paragraphtext: all play materials and all indoor and outdoor play equipment in a community care facility are suitable for the age and development of the persons in care enrolled in the community care facility, and
all play materials are safe and all play equipment is safely constructed, free from hazards and in good repair.

subsection.subsectiontext: The licensee must ensure that

paragraph.paragraphtext: a person in care who is present in a community care facility for 2 or more hours in a day is provided with a nutritious snack,
in addition to the snack provided in paragraph (a), a person in care who is present in a community care facility for 4 or more hours in a day is provided with a midday or evening meal or both,
in addition to food provided under paragraphs (a) and (b), a person in care who is present in a community care facility for 6 or more hours in a day is provided with a second nutritious snack,

in addition to the food provided under paragraphs (a) to (c), a person in care to whom overnight care is provided in a community care facility is provided with an evening nutritious snack and a morning meal, and

the food provided to a person in care is sufficient, in quantity and kind, to supply the person in care with all or part of the nutrient intake per day that is recommended by Health Canada for children and youths in the relevant age group, taking into consideration the number of hours the person in care is present in the community care facility and the person in care's food preferences and cultural background.

subsection.subsectiontext: The licensee must ensure that a person in care is not fed by means of a propped bottle.

section.sectiontext: The licensee of a community care facility as defined in section 37, 42, 52 or 57 may provide overnight care to a person in care as long as the licensee, in addition to complying with the provisions of this regulation applicable in respect of the facility,

paragraph.paragraphtext: complies with the standards of care set out in Schedule E, and
has, if overnight sleeping accommodation is provided, a satisfactory method of fire detection and second means of exit to the ground level from each floor on which a sleeping room is located.

subsection.subsectiontext: A person must not smoke in a community care facility except in an area designated as a smoking area by the licensee.
The licensee must not designate as a smoking area an area to which persons in care have access.

section.sectiontext: In this Part:

definition.def: means a person who is under 36 months of age;
means a community care facility in which group day care is provided to children.

section.sectiontext: The licensee shall provide in a community care facility

paragraph.paragraphtext: 3.7 m2 of floor area per child, excluding hallways, built in storage areas and bathrooms,
for each child, a sleeping arrangement that is not located in an activity area and consists of,

subparagraph.subparagraphtext: a crib, where the child is shorter than 90 cm (35.43") and is unable to climb out of the crib unaided, or
a mattress not less than 7.5 cm in thickness or a cot or equivalent sleeping arrangement, in any other case

section.parasandwich: with a clean washable mattress cover and clean washable covers,

paragraph.paragraphtext: for every 12 children, one toilet and one wash basin on the same floor as the community care facility,
a container for soiled clothing and a changing table that is not in the food preparation area,
in addition to the wash basins required under paragraph (c), a wash basin convenient to the changing table, and
an outdoor play area that is large enough to provide 7 m2 of play area per child.

section.marginalnote: Maximum number of hours of care
section.sectiontext: The licensee shall provide a child enrolled in a community care facility with not more than 13 hours of care per day.
The licensee shall ensure that

paragraph.paragraphtext: the children present in a community care facility are divided into groups of not more than 12, and
a separate area is available for each group of children.

section.sectiontext: The licensee shall ensure that the ratio of staff to children present in a community care facility is maintained as follows:

paragraph.paragraphtext: for each group of 4 or fewer children, one infant and toddler educator;
for each group of 5 to 8 children, one infant and toddler educator and one early childhood educator;
for each group of 9 to 12 children,

subparagraph.subparagraphtext: one infant and toddler educator,
one early childhood educator, and
one assistant.

part.parttext: Group Day Care, 30 Months to School Age

section.sectiontext: In this Part:

definition.def: means a person who is at least 30 months of age on the date of entrance to the community care facility and has not entered grade 1;
means a community care facility in which group day care is provided to children.

section.sectiontext: The licensee shall provide in a community care facility

paragraph.paragraphtext: 3.7 m2 of floor area per child, excluding hallways, built in storage areas and bathrooms,
a sleeping arrangement for each child, consisting of

subparagraph.subparagraphtext: a mattress at least 7.5 cm in thickness, or
a cot or equivalent arrangement

section.parasandwich: with a clean washable mattress cover and clean washable covers,

paragraph.paragraphtext: for every 10 children, one toilet and one wash basin,
a container for soiled clothing, and
an outdoor play area that is large enough to provide 7 m2 of play area for each child.

section.marginalnote: Maximum number of hours of care
section.sectiontext: The licensee shall provide a child enrolled in a community care facility with not more than 13 hours of care per day.

section.marginalnote: Size of group and maximum number of children under 3
section.sectiontext: The licensee shall ensure that

paragraph.paragraphtext: the children present in any one group are divided into groups of not more than 25, and
not more than 2 children under 36 months of age are provided with care in any one group at any one time.

section.sectiontext: The licensee shall ensure that the ratio of staff to children present in a community care facility is maintained as follows:

paragraph.paragraphtext: for each group of 8 or fewer children, one early childhood educator;
for each group of 9 to 16 children, one early childhood educator and one assistant;
for each group of 17 to 25 children,

subparagraph.subparagraphtext: one early childhood educator, and
2 assistants.

section.sectiontext: In this Part:

definition.def: means a person who

paragraph.paragraphtext: is at least

subparagraph.subparagraphtext: 30 months of age on the date of entrance to the community care facility, and
36 months of age on December 31 of the year of entrance to the community care facility, and

paragraph.paragraphtext: has not entered grade 1;

definition.def: means a preschool in which children are provided with opportunities for social, emotional, physical and intellectual growth.

section.sectiontext: The licensee shall provide in a community care facility

paragraph.paragraphtext: 3.7 m2 of floor area per child, excluding hallways, built in storage and bathrooms,
for every 10 children, one toilet and one wash basin, and
an outdoor play area.

section.marginalnote: Maximum number of hours of care
section.sectiontext: The licensee shall provide a child enrolled in a community care facility with not more than 4 hours of care per day.
The licensee shall ensure that the children present in a community care facility are divided into groups of not more than 20.

subsection.subsectiontext: The licensee shall ensure that the ratio of staff to children present in a community care facility is maintained as follows:

paragraph.paragraphtext: for each group of 15 or fewer children, one early childhood educator;
for each group of 16 to 20 children, one early childhood educator and one assistant.

subsection.subsectiontext: Despite subsection (1) (b), if

paragraph.paragraphtext: a community care facility has a parent education program approved by the medical health officer, and
a parent or substitute parent who has taken the program is present in the community care facility to assist the early childhood educator with a group of 16 to 20 children,

section.subsandwich: the licensee is not required to ensure that there is one assistant for that group.

section.sectiontext: In this Part:

definition.def: means a person who has not entered grade 1;
means a community care facility in which group day care is provided to children at least 25% of whom are special needs children.

section.sectiontext: The licensee shall provide in a community care facility

paragraph.paragraphtext: 4 m2 of floor area per child, excluding hallways, built in storage areas and bathrooms,
for each child who is provided with more than 4 hours of care per day, a sleeping arrangement consisting of

subparagraph.subparagraphtext: if the child is shorter than 90 cm and unable to climb out of a crib unaided, a crib, and
in any other case, a mattress at least 7.5 cm in thickness or a cot or equivalent arrangement

section.parasandwich: with a clean washable mattress cover and clean washable covers,

paragraph.paragraphtext: for every 8 children, one toilet and one wash basin that are readily accessible to the children,
a container for soiled clothing and a changing table that is not in the food preparation area,
in addition to the wash basin required under paragraph (c), a wash basin convenient to the changing table,
if a child requiring mechanical aid for mobility is enrolled in the community care facility,

subparagraph.subparagraphtext: a conveniently located and securely attached grab bar beside at least one toilet, and
a ramp for access to the community care facility, and

paragraph.paragraphtext: an outdoor play area that is large enough to provide 7 m2 of play area for each child.

section.marginalnote: Maximum number of hours of care
section.sectiontext: The licensee shall provide a child enrolled in a community care facility with not more than 13 hours of care per day.
The licensee shall ensure that

paragraph.paragraphtext: the children present in a community care facility are divided into groups,
subject to paragraphs (c) and (d), each child is placed in the group that is most appropriate for the child's needs,
not more than 16 children are in one group, and
not more than 12 children under 36 months of age are in one group.

section.sectiontext: The licensee shall ensure that the ratio of staff to children present in a community care facility is maintained as follows:

paragraph.paragraphtext: for each group of 4 or fewer children, one special needs early childhood educator;
for each group of 5 to 8 children, one special needs early childhood educator and one early childhood educator;
for each group of 9 to 12 children, one special needs early childhood educator and 2 early childhood educators;
for each group of 13 to 16 children,

subparagraph.subparagraphtext: one special needs early childhood educator,
2 early childhood educators, and
one assistant.

section.sectiontext: In this Part:

definition.def: means a person under 13 years of age;
means a community care facility in which family child care is provided, if the community care facility is the licensee's primary place of residence;
means the provision, primarily by the licensee, of

paragraph.paragraphtext: care to children, and
opportunities for the social, emotional, physical and intellectual growth of children.

section.sectiontext: The licensee shall provide in a community care facility

paragraph.paragraphtext: a sleeping arrangement for each child consisting of

subparagraph.subparagraphtext: where the child is shorter than 90 cm and unable to climb out of a crib unaided, a crib, and
in any other case, a mattress at least 7.5 cm in thickness or a cot or equivalent arrangement

section.parasandwich: with a clean washable mattress cover and clean washable covers,

paragraph.paragraphtext: a container for soiled clothing and a changing table that is not in the food preparation area,
an indoor play area, and
an outdoor play area.

section.marginalnote: Maximum number of hours of care
section.sectiontext: The licensee shall provide a child enrolled in a community care facility with not more than 13 hours of care per day.

subsection.subsectiontext: The licensee must ensure that not more than a total of 7 children are cared for or live in a community care facility at one time, and, within this total number, the licensee must ensure that

paragraph.paragraphtext: not more than 5 children are preschool age;
not more than 3 children are under 3 years of age;
not more than 1 child is under the age of 12 months.

subsection.subsectiontext: For the purposes of this section child does not include a person who is 12 years of age or older and who is related by blood or marriage to the licensee or care provider.

section.sectiontext: In this Part:

definition.def: means a person who

paragraph.paragraphtext: attends school, and
is under 13 years of age;

definition.def: means a community care facility for out of school care;
means the provision of care, before and after school hours and during school holidays, for children attending school;
includes kindergarten.

section.sectiontext: The licensee shall provide in a community care facility

paragraph.paragraphtext: 3 m2 of floor area per child, excluding hallways, built in storage and bathrooms,
for every 15 children, one toilet and one wash basin, and
an outdoor play area.

section.marginalnote: Maximum number of hours of care
section.sectiontext: The licensee shall provide a child enrolled in a community care facility with not more than 13 hours of care per day.

subsection.subsectiontext: Where any child present in a community care facility is in kindergarten or grade 1, the licensee shall ensure that the children are divided into groups of not more than 20.
Where every child present in a community care facility is in a grade higher than grade 1, the licensee shall ensure that the children are divided into groups of not more than 25.

section.sectiontext: The licensee shall ensure that the ratio of staff to children present in a community care facility is maintained as follows:

paragraph.paragraphtext: where any child present in a group in the community care facility is in kindergarten or grade 1,

subparagraph.subparagraphtext: one responsible adult for every group of 10 or fewer children, and
2 responsible adults for every group of 11 to 20 children;

paragraph.paragraphtext: where every child present in a group in the community care facility is in a grade higher than grade 1,

subparagraph.subparagraphtext: one responsible adult for every group of 15 or fewer children, and
2 responsible adults for every group of 16 to 25 children.

section.sectiontext: Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 217/2004, App. 2, s. 5.]
A licensee must ensure that each person in care in a residential care facility is less than 19 years of age.

subsection.subsectiontext: The licensee shall provide in a residential care facility

paragraph.paragraphtext: a dining area

subparagraph.subparagraphtext: with at least 1 m2 of floor space per person in care, and
that allows a person in care requiring a wheelchair to eat at a table while seated in the wheelchair,

paragraph.paragraphtext: a suitably furnished indoor activity room with at least 1 m2 of floor space per person in care for the maximum number of persons in care using the room at any one time,
for every 5 persons in care, one toilet and one wash basin, and
for every 10 persons in care, one bathtub equipped with shower.

subsection.subsectiontext: If a building or structure is licensed for residential care under section 4 (1) (b) (ii) of the Act on or after the effective date of this subsection, the licensee must provide in the building or structure

paragraph.paragraphtext: interconnecting smoke alarms, installed in each bedroom and in each corridor leading to a bedroom,

sprinklers which comply with the requirements of NFPA 13D (standard for the installation of sprinkler systems in one- and two-family dwellings and mobile homes) and have had the plans, design and installation approved (to include sprinklers in all washrooms) and a program of routine testing of the system approved,
an approved adequate water supply for fire fighting,
not less than a 45 minute fire separation between each garage attached to the building or structure, and
emergency lighting which will automatically illuminate the corridors and stairs for a minimum of 30 minutes in the event of a power failure.

section.sectiontext: Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 217/2004, App. 2, s. 5.]
Where a person in care requiring mechanical aid for mobility resides in a residential care facility, the licensee shall ensure that

paragraph.paragraphtext: the window sill of the person in care's bedroom is not more than 80 cm above the floor,
the person in care has access to all public areas, entrances and exits, and
the washroom is suitably equipped for the person in care's needs.

subsection.subsectiontext: The licensee shall ensure

paragraph.paragraphtext: that

subparagraph.subparagraphtext: no person in care is required to share a bedroom except with one other person in care, and
no person in care over 6 years of age is required to share a bedroom with another person in care unless both persons in care are of the same sex, and

paragraph.paragraphtext: that each bedroom complies with and is furnished in accordance with the standards set out in subsections (2) to (8).

subsection.subsectiontext: The floor area of the bedroom, excluding clothes closets, must be at least

paragraph.paragraphtext: where one person in care is accommodated, 7.4 m2, or
where more than one person in care is accommodated, 5.6 m2 per person in care.

subsection.subsectiontext: For each person in care requiring a wheelchair, a floor area of not less than 1 m2 per person in care must be provided in addition to the floor area required under subsection (2).
The bedroom must be dry, well ventilated and directly accessible from a hall without passing through another room.
The bedroom must have an exterior window

paragraph.paragraphtext: with a glass area equal to not less than 10% of the floor area of the room, and
that, where air conditioning is not provided, can be opened for ventilation.

subsection.subsectiontext: The bedroom must have sufficient artificial lighting to provide a minimum of 300 lx of general lighting and a minimum of 500 lx of lighting at the person in care's bed and chair.
Each person in care must be provided with

paragraph.paragraphtext: a bed for the exclusive use of the person in care, and
additional furniture, appropriate for the age level of the person in care, for storage of clothing and possessions.

subsection.subsectiontext: Where 2 persons in care are accommodated in one bedroom in which personal care is given, screening must be provided.

section.marginalnote: Staff to persons in care ratio

subsection.subsectiontext: The licensee shall maintain at all times a ratio of staff to persons in care present appropriate to the needs of the persons in care and the type of care required.
In this section staff means responsible adults.

section.sectiontext: In this Part:

definition.def: means a person who has not entered grade 1;
means a community care facility for emergency care;
means the provision, on a short term basis, of care, including emotional support and an opportunity for social and intellectual development, in a group setting for children.

subsection.subsectiontext: Section 43 (a) to (d) applies in respect of a community care facility.
The licensee shall provide in a community care facility an outdoor play area that is

paragraph.paragraphtext: readily accessible from the community care facility.
Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 395/95, s. 15.]

section.marginalnote: Maximum number of hours of care
section.sectiontext: The licensee shall provide a child enrolled in a community care facility with not more than 72 hours of care per calendar month.
The licensee shall ensure that

paragraph.paragraphtext: children under 3 years of age who are present in a community care facility are divided into groups of not more than 12, and
children 3 years of age or more who are present in a community care facility are divided into groups of not more than 25.

section.sectiontext: The licensee shall ensure that the ratio of staff to children present in a community care facility is maintained in accordance with

paragraph.paragraphtext: section 41, for children under 3 years of age, and
section 46, for children 3 years of age or more.

part.parttext: Child Minding, 18 Months to School Age

section.sectiontext: In this Part:

definition.def: means a person who is at least 18 months of age and has not entered grade 1;
means the provision of supervised group care for children;
means a child minding community care facility.

section.sectiontext: The licensee shall provide in a community care facility

paragraph.paragraphtext: 3 m2 of floor space per child, excluding hallways, built in storage and bathrooms,
for every 10 children, one toilet and one wash basin,
a container for soiled clothing and a changing table, and
in addition to the wash basin required under paragraph (b), a wash basin convenient to the changing table.

section.marginalnote: Maximum number of hours of care
section.sectiontext: The licensee shall provide a child enrolled in a community care facility with

paragraph.paragraphtext: not more than 3 hours of care per day, and
not more than 2 days of care per week.

subsection.subsectiontext: Where any child present in a group is under 3 years of age, the licensee shall ensure that the children are divided into groups of not more than 16.
Where every child present in a group is 3 years of age or more, the licensee shall ensure that the children are divided into groups of not more than 20.

section.sectiontext: The licensee shall ensure that the ratio of staff to children present in a community care facility is maintained as follows:

paragraph.paragraphtext: where every child in a group is 3 years of age or more,

subparagraph.subparagraphtext: one responsible adult for each group of 8 or fewer children,
2 responsible adults for each group of 9 to 16 children, and
3 responsible adults for each group of 17 to 20 children;

paragraph.paragraphtext: where a child in a group is under 3 years of age,

subparagraph.subparagraphtext: one responsible adult for each group of 4 or fewer children,
2 responsible adults for each group of 5 to 8 children,
3 responsible adults for each group of 9 to 12 children, and
4 responsible adults for each group of 13 to 16 children.

part.parttext: Occasional Child Care at Ski Hill or Resort

section.sectiontext: In this Part:

definition.def: means a person who is at least 18 months of age and under 6 years of age;
means a community care facility for the provision of occasional, casual, short term, supervised care for children at a ski hill or a resort;
means a place as described in section 80.3.

section.marginalnote: Maximum number of hours of care
section.sectiontext: The licensee must not provide a child enrolled in a community care facility with

paragraph.paragraphtext: more than 40 hours of care during a calendar month, and
more than 8 hours of care a day.

subsection.subsectiontext: A licensee must include each child in a community care facility in a group that

paragraph.paragraphtext: contains not more than 24 places at any one time,
has the required number of responsible adult staff members specified under section 80.4, and
has a separate area available for use of the children in the group.

subsection.subsectiontext: Provided that the requirements of subsection (1) are met for each group, there may be more than one group at a community care facility.
For the purpose of calculating the number of places in a group,

paragraph.paragraphtext: each child over 36 months of age in the group must be considered to be occupying one of these places, and
each child 36 months of age or younger in the group must be considered to be occupying two of these places.

section.sectiontext: A licensee must ensure that the ratio of staff to children in a group at the community care facility at any one time is at least

paragraph.paragraphtext: 1 responsible adult staff member for 7 or fewer places,
2 responsible adult staff members for 8 places to 16 places, and
3 responsible adult staff members for 17 places to 24 places.

section.marginalnote: Requirements for use of a community care facility
section.sectiontext: The licensee must ensure that the parent of a child in the community care facility is actively participating in a recreational activity offered at the resort or ski hill.
The licensee must provide in a community care facility

paragraph.paragraphtext: 3 m2 of floor space for each child, excluding hallways, bathrooms, food preparation areas, storage areas, staff office, or any other area not used by children as an activity area,
for every 10 children, one toilet and one wash basin,
a container for soiled clothing, and
a sleeping arrangement for each child, consisting of

subparagraph.subparagraphtext: a mattress at least 7.5 cm in thickness with clean washable mattress cover and clean washable covers, or
a cot with clean washable covers.

section.marginalnote: Special requirements for children less than 36 months old

subsection.subsectiontext: The licensee must provide for each child less than 36 months of age who will receive care in the community care facility for more than 4 hours a day, a separate sleeping area located away from an activity area that consists of a crib, if the child is shorter than 90 cm and is unable to climb out of the crib unaided, or

paragraph.paragraphtext: a mattress not less than 7.5 cm in thickness, or
a cot.

subsection.subsectiontext: A crib or mattress under subsection (1) must include a clean, waterproof, washable mattress cover and clean washable covers.
A cot under subsection (1) must include clean washable covers.
A community care facility for children less than 36 months of age must include

paragraph.paragraphtext: a diaper changing area adjacent to the activity area, but not in the food preparation area,
a diaper changing table with a surface that is padded, non-absorbent and easy to clean, and
in addition to the wash basins required under section 80.6 (b), a wash basin convenient to the changing table.

subsection.subsectiontext: Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 217/2004, App. 2, s. 5.]
Sections 38 (a), 43 (a) and 48 (a) do not apply in respect of a facility if a licence was issued for the facility before this section comes into force.

section.sectiontext: Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 217/2004, App. 2, s. 5.]

subsection.subsectiontext: Despite the re-enactment of section 11, a person holding a letter of permission issued before the re-enactment of section 11 may continue to exercise the benefits and privileges acquired under the letter in accordance with any terms or conditions contained in the letter until the earlier of

paragraph.paragraphtext: the expiry of the letter of permission, or

subsection.subsectiontext: This section is repealed effective June 1, 2005.

• Provide indoor and outdoor activities that encourage the development of large and small muscle skills appropriate to each person in care's level of development.
• Promote the development of self-help skills.
• Encourage good health and safety habits.
• Develop a flexible daily program that responds to the needs and interests of the persons in care.
• Provide an environment that facilitates the development of curiosity, reasoning and problem-solving skills.
• Provide age-appropriate activities which encourage development of the following concept-building skills: classifying, ordering, determining direction and perceiving spatial relationships.
• Provide activities and materials that encourage creative endeavours such as art, music, movement, imaginative play, story-telling and construction.
• Provide activities and materials that foster a greater understanding of the environment.
• Model good language and listening skills.
• Provide opportunities for persons in care to develop receptive and expressive language skills.
• Encourage communication.
• Help persons in care develop a positive self-concept.
• Help persons in care develop an accurate perception of self.
• Help persons in care express positive and negative feelings in appropriate ways.
• Provide a comfortable atmosphere in which persons in care feel proud of their cultural heritage and cultural sharing is encouraged.
• Provide an environment for persons in care to work independently and to share and work cooperatively in small groups.
• Provide an environment that fosters positive behaviour in persons in care.
• Help persons in care appreciate differences and respect the personal feelings and property of others.
• Provide opportunities for social interactions that help persons in care develop appropriate skills for social relationships.
• Provide experiences that facilitate a person in care's feeling of belonging to family, community and the world at large.

schedule.scheduletitle: Schedule E— Standards for Overnight Care
schedule.lefttext: 1 No more than 4 persons in care may be accommodated in one room.
2 No person in care over 6 years of age may be accommodated in a room shared by another person in care of the opposite sex without direct staff supervision.
3 There must be a minimum of 5 m2 floor space per person in care in the sleeping area.

subsection.subsectiontext: directly accessible without passing through another sleeping area,
dry, well ventilated and free from draughts, and
clean and free from clutter and other extraneous or unsafe matter.

schedule.lefttext: 5Each person in care must be provided

subsection.subsectiontext: with

paragraph.paragraphtext: a crib, if the person in care is shorter than 90 cm (35.43") and is unable to climb out of the crib unaided, or
a cot or bed, in any other case, and

subsection.subsectiontext: with a clean mattress and sufficient sheets and coverings for warmth and comfort.

schedule.lefttext: 6 Cribs, cots and beds must be arranged so as to allow easy access to each person in care with a minimum of 90 cm (3') of space on at least 2 sides of each crib, cot or bed.
7 Notwithstanding any other provision of this regulation, one shower or bathtub must be provided for every 10 persons in care and adequate hot water must be provided.
8 No animals may be permitted in the sleeping area.
9 If 3 or more persons in care are sleeping overnight in a community care facility,

subsection.subsectiontext: a responsible adult must at all times

paragraph.paragraphtext: be awake and accessible to the persons in care, or
be sleeping in the same room as the persons in care, and

subsection.subsectiontext: the number of other staff required to maintain the applicable ratio of staff to persons in care must be available in the community care facility.

section.sectiontext: For the purpose of this regulation, any of the following is a reportable incident:

definition.def: means aggressive or unusual behaviour by a person in care towards other persons, including another person in care, which has not been appropriately assessed in the individual's care plan;
means an attempt by a person in care to take his or her own life;
means any death of a person in care;
means an outbreak or the occurrence of a disease above the incident level that is normally expected;
means any use of a restraint that is not approved and documented in the care plan of a person in care;
means any act, or lack of action, which may diminish the sense of well-being of a person in care, perpetrated by a person not in care, such as verbal harassment, yelling or confinement;
means a fall of such seriousness, experienced by a person in care, as to require emergency care by a physician or transfer to a hospital;
means

paragraph.paragraphtext: the misuse of the funds and assets of a person in care by a person not in care, or
the obtaining of the property and funds of a person in care by a person not in care without the knowledge and full consent of the person in care or their substitute decision maker;

definition.def: means an error in the administration of a medication which adversely affects a person in care or requires emergency intervention or transfer to a hospital;
means a person in care who is missing;
means an injury to a person in care that occurs during transit by motor vehicle while the person is under the care and supervision of the licensee;
means the failure of a care provider to meet the needs of a person in care, including food, shelter, care or supervision;
means an injury to a person in care requiring emergency care by a physician or transfer to a hospital;
means any physical force that is excessive for, or is inappropriate to, a situation involving a person in care and perpetrated by a person not in care;
means the ingestion of a poison or toxic substance by a person in care;

means any condition or event which could reasonably be expected to impair the ability of the licensee, or the employees of the licensee, to provide care or which affects the health, safety or well-being of persons in care;
means any sexual behaviour directed towards a person in care by an employee of the licensee, a volunteer or any other person in a position of trust, power or authority and includes

paragraph.paragraphtext: any sexual exploitation, whether consensual or not, and

sexual activity between persons in care if the difference in age or power between them is so significant that the older or more powerful person in care is clearly taking sexual advantage of the younger or less powerful person in care;

definition.def: means any unexpected illness of such seriousness that it requires a person in care to receive emergency care by a physician or transfer to a hospital.
